org.mmbase.datatypes.processors

Class FormatFileSize

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mmbase.datatypes.processors.FormatQuantity
      • org.mmbase.datatypes.processors.FormatFileSize
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Processor

    public class FormatFileSize
extends FormatQuantity
    A processor that gets a number as a file-size, that is, rounded with kbytes and Mb's and so on. Actually, using setters like FormatQuantity.setUnit(String), this class can also be used to postfix all other kinds of units to integers. The unit symbol used is 'B', the IEEE 1541 recommended symbol for a 'byte'. Use setClassical(boolean) or FormatQuantity.setUnit(java.lang.String) if you prefer the non-standard, but once common 'byte' as a unit.
    Since:
    MMBase-1.8
    Version:
    $Id$
    Author:
    Michiel Meeuwissen
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • setClassical

        public void setClassical(boolean c)
        It was commonplace to mix SI prefixes with 'binary' factors. If this is set to 'true', then SI prefixes are used and 'byte' will be the unit symbol, and 1024 the basic factor (which basically adheres to no recommendation or standard, but is widely used by e.g. hard disk manufacturers). If this is set to 'false'. then then IEEE prefixes are used, and 'B' will be the unit. Using this method with 'true' is the only way to get a multiplication factor which does not correspond to the set of prefixes. Normally FormatQuantity.setBinaryPrefixes(boolean) can be used to toggle between IEEE and SI mode.
        Parameters:
        c - boolean
        Since:
        MMBase-1.9
